awd_titl_txt: Defining Multiscale, Rate-Dependent Damage Mechanisms in Blood Vessels
awd_abstract_narration:
Blood vessels can be damaged as a result of large shape changes – deformations – that occur in both accidents (such as traumatic brain injury) and surgery (such as angioplasty).  However,  little is known about how this damage affects a vessel’s ability to continue to perform its function.  This is especially true when damage is subtle and there is no bleeding. Additionally, recent research shows that the rate of deformation influences the type of resulting damage. The goals of this project are to define damage mechanisms in blood vessels and to define how damage changes vessel function. The project focuses on blood vessels in the brain. The results  of this project will provide insight about damage mechanisms in traumatic brain injury, and may eventually lead to better healthcare treatments. This information will improve design criteria for automobiles, helmets, and other protective devices. It may also reveal factors that increase the risk of stroke after brain injury. It may also improve outcomes of balloon angioplasty procedures. Researchers involved in this project will include students from underrepresented groups, who will gain valuable professional development.

The aims of this project are (1) to differentiate and quantify contributions of both recoverable (e.g. viscoelasticity) and non-recoverable (e.g. collagen unfolding) mechanisms of vessel softening, and (2) to define the influence of strain rate on mechanisms of damage. Microstructural damage and associated softening will be defined using isolated blood vessels subjected to overstretch through a range of strain rates. Experimental findings will be incorporated into a novel constitutive model that relates multiscale damage of passive vessel constituents with mechanical behavior. This is a critical first step toward predicting disease development and/or recovery after injury. While the research focuses on blood vessels, findings are expected to also apply to other soft tissues. Results will advance injury prevention strategies and provide a foundation for optimization of design for both interventional procedures and implantable biomaterials and devices. These experiments will inform computer models that predict damage-induced changes in vessel behavior. Finally, the research will further develop methods for characterizing soft tissue damage, including collagen hybridizing peptide to quantify collagen damage.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The reported research on vessel softening and collagen unfolding represents a significant advance in the understanding of injury and damage in blood vessels, and of soft tissues more generally. These findings specifically characterize how changes in vessel microstructure relate to damage-induced softening. As part of this, loading direction and rate were both considered, as was the possibility of recovery from damage. The work also defines important relationships that can be used to define and validate models of damage in soft tissue, including those used to define how blood vessels respond to loading associated with both traumatic brain injury and balloon angioplasty. We expect that the fidelity of models simulating these mechanisms of injury will be dramatically improved.

The most significant broader impact of this research is our recognition that vessel softening may play an important role in traumatic brain injury (TBI) pathophysiology. Magnetic resonance elastography (MRE) shows that the brain is softer (i.e., less stiff) following an injury event. Because blood vessels are known to play an important role in brain stiffness properties, it is logical that softened vessels would result in a softer brain. More work is needed to better understand this phenomenon, and to account for other factors like edema and hemorrhage, but this realization could lead to significant advancements in characterizing patient injury and progress toward recovery. It could also lead to new, more advanced techniques for validation of computational TBI models. Findings may also lead to impactful advancements in balloon angioplasty procedures, where there is currently little known about how loading conditions influence procedural success.

Research findings have been incorporated into an advanced course (undergrad and grad) on soft tissue biomechanics. Soft tissue damage mechanics principles have also been taught to teenage students and their parents, in some cases, through multiple seminars and workshops at the University of Utah.

As noted above, accurate identification of collagen damage in blood vessel injury, as well as improved understanding of the influence of strain rate on tissue damage, is expected to add insight into diagnosis of subtle injury resulting from mild traumatic brain injury, as well as guide development of improved strategies for balloon angioplasty.

In total, this project directly contributed to the research training of 7 graduate (5 PhD and 2 MS) and 6 undergraduate students. Four of these have moved on to advanced academic study or to professional positions in academia or industry. The remainder are continuing their research training.


Last Modified: 10/09/2024
Modified by: Kenneth L Monson

Images (1 of )
  • Mean percent change in baseline stiffness as a function of in vivo-normalized overstretch and overstretch rate. The plot shows that softening is a linear function of overstretch (beyond the threshold shown) and that rate of overstretch did not play a significant role.
    Noah Robert Pearson
    Public Domain
    Kenneth L Monson
    Softening is not a function of overstretch rate
  • Representative images of adventitial tropocollagen denaturation in vessels stretched axially at low (left) and high (right) rates. The first row consists of controls; corresponding damaged vessels are displayed vertically beneath.
    Noah Robert Pearson
    Public Domain
    Kenneth L Monson
    Collagen denaturation as a function of strain rate
  • Overstretch-induced softening patterns for native and collagen-digested vessels are indistinguishable.
    Joseph D. Bail
    Public Domain
    Kenneth L Monson
    Softening patterns in native v. collagen-degraded vessels
